abstracts.cdata!:
The First and Second Development Policy
            Loan in Support of the Plan Maroc Vert received a moderately
            satisfactory outcome rating with significant risk to
            development outcome. The Bank received a satisfactory rating
            for its performance while the Borrower received a moderately
            satisfactory performance rating. No restructurings took
            place during the life of this project. Country developments
            led to three changes in the agreed prior actions for the
            second operation. These changes were: (a) the substitution
            of an agreement on the management model at Berkane for the
            previously proposed action on three wholesale market pilot
            projects. The concept remained the same but essentially the
            target was reduced from three to one. (b) The addition of
            the executive decision on market liberalization for red meat
            to the proposed action on concession to the private sector
            of modernized municipal slaughterhouses. (c) The
            substitution of the transmission of the draft laws creating
            the Regional Agriculture and Rural Development Offices
            (ORDARs) for the previously proposed action raising
            irrigation tariffs. There were several lessons learned from
            this project including the following: (1) A development
            policy loan (DPL) works best when it stems from a home-grown
            reform program with strong ownership within government. (2)
            A further strong value of Bank support under a DPL is to
            help create a platform for agencies that otherwise may have
            divergent agendas. (3) The linking of a DPL to a sectoral
            medium-term expenditure framework (MTEF) aligns incentives
            for both the finance ministry and the line ministry, and
            provides investment resources to accompany and help
            implement reforms that otherwise might not take place or
            might not yield their intended returns. (4) In the case of
            Morocco, submission of draft legislation to the Government
            General Secretary (SGG) may be inadequate assurance that a
            reform will be promptly executed. (5) Evaluation of a DPO is
            constrained by the short time scale, particularly for a two
            loan series, where the final evaluation occurs only twelve
            months after the second set of prior actions. (6) There is a
            need  and an opportunity  to accompany some reforms with
            project-style guidance and investment.
